This composer often collaborated with Merce Cunningham and utilized the “gamut technique.” This composer composed “Music of Changes” which used the I Ching (“ee cheeng”), and another piece by this composer uses a specially crafted organ that plays for 639 (*) years. A “prepared” piano was used in a piece by this composer of As Slow as Possible, and features them sitting at a piano in silence for the title amount of time. For 10 points, name this American composer of 4’33”.

This composer’s Introduction and Rondo Capriccioso, incorporating Spanish dance motifs, was composed for Pablo de Sarasate. One of this composer’s pieces quotes the Dies Irae in a waltz theme, and features a violin with its high E string tuned down a (*) half step. That piece also has a similar xylophone part to the Fossils movement of a suite that contains other movements like The Elephant and The Swan. For 10 points, name this French composer of Danse Macabre and Carnival of the Animals.

During this war, Irving Berlin’s song “White Christmas” was used to signal one event. A memorial for this war features a Frederick Hart statue of three soldiers. Malcolm Browne photographed a car with an open hood next to a man committing suicide during this war. A wall with over 50,000 names is part of a V-shaped memorial to this war designed by (*) Maya Lin. A photo taken during this war shows a line of people waiting to board a helicopter on the roof of a CIA safe house. A Buddhist monk set himself on fire to protest this war. A naked girl is shown running away from a napalm attack during,  what war in Southeast Asia?

This composer collaborated with the lyricist Irving Caesar on the song “Swanee.” In one of this composer’s operas, Sportin’ Life questions the Bible in the song “It Ain't Necessarily So.” In an aria from that opera, Clara sings that “The fish are jumpin’/and the cotton is high.” That aria, (*) “Summertime,” is set on Catfish Row. This composer famously used taxi horns in another piece, and wrote many pieces with their brother Ira. Another piece by this composer begins with a clarinet trill and glissando. For 10 points, name this composer of “An American in Paris” and “Rhapsody in Blue.”

This painting is analyzed in the introduction of Michel Foucault’s The Order of Things. This painting is set in a room in Alcazar Palace, where a small mirror in the background reflects Mariana of Austria. A man at the left of this painting has the (*) cross of the Order of St. James on his clothing and is believed to be its painter. A child rests a foot on a dog on the right side of the painting, while a girl in a large white dress is in the center. For 10 points, name this painting titled for the attendants to the Infanta Margarita, painted by Diego Velazquez.

One piece for this instrument imitates flutes and french horns with ricochet and is nicknamed “The Hunt.” Giuseppe Tartini composed a sonata for this instrument, titled “Devil’s Trill.” 24 caprices for this instrument were written by Niccolo Paganini, who played one of these instruments made by the luthier (*) Antonio Stradivari. The concertmaster of an orchestra plays this instrument, whose highest string is an E. For 10 points, name this highest-pitched string instrument.

In a painting of this type, the monkey Fulang-Chang has a pink ribbon around his neck that attaches him to its other central figure. In another work of this type, an Ionic column replaces the spine of a woman who appears wearing a necklace of (*) thorns in a third example of these works. A woman with a prominent unibrow often features in Frida Kahlo’s works of this type. For 10 points, name this type of artwork, in which the artist depicts themself.

Only this figure’s head and neck appear in the Athenaeum Portrait, the best known work of Gilbert Stuart. Grant Wood painted this figure holding an ax in Parson Weems’ Fable, which depicts a myth in which he cuts a cherry tree. This man titles Emmanuel (*) Leutze’s most famous painting, in which James Monroe holds an American flag in a boat floating on an icy river. For 10 points, name this man depicted “crossing the Delaware” in one painting, the first U. S. President.

One work by this composer features a bass echo a B-flat major melody played by the trombone in the “Tuba Mirum” section. This composer’s requiem in D minor was commissioned by Count von Walsegg and completed by Franz Süssmayr after his death in 1791. The only two symphonies in a minor key by this composer are the (*) “Little” and “Great” G minor symphonies. For 10 points, name this Austrian composer of the “Jupiter” Symphony and The Magic Flute.

Pink banana flesh appears under a yellow peel in this artist’s design for the cover of the Velvet Underground’s debut album. This artist used mesh to transfer ink onto a canvas to create portraits of an actress in his Marilyn Diptych, which was made using silk-screening. This artist, who worked at the Factory, created (*) thirty-two paintings that only differ in the labels of varieties like “split pea” and “tomato.” For 10 points, name this Pop artist, who painted Campbell’s soup cans.

The development of a D major piece in sonata form is typically in this note’s major key, since it is the dominant of the D major scale. The “Verdi pitch” sets this note to a 432 Hertz frequency, instead of the 440 Hertz concert pitch. This note’s minor key does not contain any sharps or flats, as it is the relative minor of C major, while its (*) major key has 3 sharps. An oboe plays this note to help the orchestra tune. For 10 points, name this second note in a G major scale.

This architect was inspired by Anasazi Cliff Dwellings to design the Mesa Laboratory. One of this architect’s buildings resembles growing bamboo shoots, while another building features a dual-triangular tent that sits on the shores of Lake Erie. This man designed the (*) Bank of China and Cleveland’s Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. For 10 points, name this Chinese-American architect, who designed the glass pyramid for the Louvre.

In 1994, thieves stealing this painting left a note reading “Thanks for the poor security.” This painting, the most famous of its painter’s series The Frieze of Life, sees two men walking on a bridge behind the central figure. The eruption of Krakatoa may have inspired the (*) red sky in this painting, set on a fjord overlooking Oslo. For 10 points, name this painting by Edvard Munch, in which a figure holds his face while doing the title action.

Jean-Jacques Rousseau arranged this work for solo flute, and its last movement utilizes pizzicato strings to depict rain. This work is performed alongside sonnet texts such as “the drunkards have fallen asleep,” and includes a viola playing “always forte” to depict a barking dog. This work was included in the composer’s (*) Contest Between Invention and Harmony. For 10 points, name this set of four violin concertos composed by Antonio Vivaldi.

In one opera by this composer, a B-minor clarinet solo opens a tenor aria titled “E lucevan le stelle.” The title character of one opera by this composer kills Baron Scarpia after he orders the execution of her lover, Mario Cavaradossi. Another opera by this composer of Tosca and Turandot sees the title character singing the aria (*) “Un bel dì” while waiting for Lieutenant Pinkerton to return. For 10 points, name this Italian opera composer of Madame Butterfly.

A sculpture of one of these animals sits atop the Thunder Stone, the largest stone ever moved by people. The leg of one of these animals sits atop a cannonball in another statue honoring Erasmo de Narni. Etienne Falconet designed a sculpture of the founder of (*) St. Petersburg with a bronze one of these animals, another of which features in Donatello’s Gattamelatta. For 10 points, name these animals, which are depicted with their riders in equestrian statues.

A song by this composer features a chord progression used in Dizzy Gillespie’s “Salt Peanuts.” A blues-inspired aria about when “the livin’ is easy” was created by this composer of “I Got Rhythm” for an opera set in Charleston’s Catfish Row. A train ride to Boston inspired this composer of (*) “Summertime” to write a piece which begins with Ross Gorman’s improvised clarinet glissando. For 10 points, name this composer of Porgy and Bess and Rhapsody in Blue.

This art style was practiced by the Americans Childe Hassan and Mary Cassatt. Louis Leroy coined this movement’s name while insulting a painting of a sunrise above a harbor. An artist in this movement made multiple paintings in different times of day of the (*) Rouen Cathedral and haystacks. That artist in this movement had a garden in Giverny, where he painted water lilies. For 10 points, name this art style practiced by Claude Monet.

This instrument’s predecessor, the chalumeau, names the first register of this instrument. Players of this instrument can “cross the break” to reach the second “clarion” register. Anton Stadler was the dedicatee of an A major concerto for this instrument by Mozart. Aaron Copland dedicated his concerto for this instrument to (*) Benny Goodman. For 10 points, name this single-reeded woodwind instrument, pitched in B-flat, that is held similarly to the oboe.

Jean-Jacques Rousseau arranged this work for solo flute, and its last movement utilizes pizzicato strings to depict rain. This work is performed alongside sonnet texts, such as “the drunkards have fallen asleep.” This work includes a viola playing “always forte” to depict a barking dog. This work was included in the composer’s (*) Contest Between Invention and Harmony. For 10 points, name this set of four violin concertos, composed by Antonio Vivaldi.

This man sculpted the Rebellious Slave and the Dying Slave for his design for the tomb of Pope Julius II, for which he also sculpted a horned Moses. This man depicted an unusually young and triangular Mary holding the dead body of Jesus in his only signed sculpture, (*) Pietà. In a marble sculpture by this man, the title figure holds a slingshot used to kill Goliath. For 10 points, name this sculptor of a marble David, who also painted the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel.

A Paul Gonsalves saxophone solo on this man’s “Diminuendo and Crescendo in Blue” at the 1956 Newport Jazz Festival helped revive his career. To “parallel to the history of the Negro in America,” this man composed Black, Brown, and Beige. This frequent performer at the Cotton Club composed (*) “Mood Indigo.” Billy Strayhorn and this man collaborated on a song about “the quickest way to Harlem.” For 10 points, name this jazz pianist of “Take the A Train,” who has a royal name.

Two lamps appear to hang from a medallion in an artwork of this type named for the town of Ardabil. To depict the title figures’ status, a red one of these objects is placed on a table in The Ambassadors, whose artist, Hans Holbein, often painted them. The asymmetrical Senneh knot was used in (*) Persian examples of these artworks, which often feature flowers and Kufic Arabic calligraphy on them. Muslims pray on,  what textiles, which are used to decorate floors?

This painting is analyzed in the preface to Michel Foucault’s The Order of Things. Juan del Mazo’s copies of two paintings by Peter Paul Rubens appear in the background of this painting. The artist of this painting appears with a red cross on his chest while working at an easel. A (*) dwarf and a dog are part of the entourage of the Infanta Margarita in this painting. For 10 points, name this painting of the “maids of honor” in a Spanish court by Diego Velazquez.

It’s not Spain, but one composer from this country was accused of plagiarizing his Rapsodie espagnole, which appears in his Miroirs suite. This country was home to the composer of a “habanera,” in which a woman sings that “love is a rebellious bird.” In an opera by a composer from this country, the toreador (*) Escamillo feuds with Don Jose. For 10 points, name this country home to Maurive Ravel and the composer of Carmen, George Bizet.

One work by this composer includes a 7/4 Finale that follows a solo bassoon Berceuse. In that work by this composer, a timpani roll introduces the “Infernal Dance,” while another of his ballets begins with an “Adoration of the Earth” and features a (*) high bassoon solo. This composer of The Firebird wrote a ballet that caused a riot at its premier, due to its depiction of a pagan girl dancing herself to death. For 10 points, name this Russian composer of The Rite of Spring.

A 1909 plan for this city was named for Daniel Burnham, who also named an architecture firm with John Root based in this city. Mies van der Rohe designed a set of apartments for the Lake Shore Drive in this city. The 1893 world’s fair in this city saw the construction of its (*) Art Institute. This city’s “Loop” area is the home of the Willis Tower. For 10 points, name this most populous city in Illinois.

One work by this composer begins with a solo melody of long C, followed by sixteenth notes B, G, E, B, then a long A. One work by this composer includes a 7/4 Finale that follows a solo bassoon Berceuse (“bear-seews”). In that work by this composer, a timpani roll introduces the “Infernal Dance” while another of his ballets begins with an (*) “Adoration of the Earth” that features a high bassoon solo. This composer’s most famous ballet caused a riot at its premier and depicts a pagan girl dancing herself to death. For 10 points, name this Russian composer of The Firebird and The Rite of Spring.

A word meaning “karma” appears in the bottom left corner of a painting by this artist where the central figure is shot with nine arrows. Two lovers in this artist’s Two Nudes in a Forest appear in another of their paintings in which a skyscraper erupts out of a volcano. An Ionic column replaces this artist’s (*) spine in a self-portrait painted after a bus accident. A blood vessel connects a baby to this artist in Henry Ford Hospital, painted after she miscarried a baby fathered by her husband Diego Rivera. For 10 points, name this Mexican artist whose many self-portraits feature her unibrow.

This architect names a “plan” that was designed as an urban redevelopment initiative for Oklahoma City. This architect was inspired by Anasazi (“an-uh-SAH-zee”) Cliff Dwellings to design the Mesa Laboratory. One of this architect’s buildings resembles growing bamboo shoots while another building features a dual-triangular tent that sits on the shores of (*) Lake Erie. This man designed the Bank of China and Cleveland’s Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. For 10 points, name this Chinese-American architect who designed the glass pyramid for the Louvre.

On this painting’s left, a man wearing a Scottish checkerboard bonnet faces away from a Black man. An Allied bombing raid on Bremen destroyed the original copy of this painting, in which a body of water its artist had not seen was based on the Rhine. Three women stand in front of this (*) painting in a work satirizing critics of a World War I memorial by Grant Wood. A historically inaccurate flag in this painting is held by James Monroe, who stands in a boat in an icy river. For 10 points, name this Emmanuel Leutze (“loyt-suh”) painting, in which the title first president travels to the Battle of Trenton.

In one opera by this composer, the aria “Recondita Armonia” is sung by a painter who compares his lover favorably to a model for a painting of Mary Magdalene. In that opera by this composer, a B-minor clarinet solo opens a tenor aria titled “E lucevan le stelle.” The title character of one opera by this composer kills Baron Scarpia after he orders the (*) execution of her lover Mario Cavaradossi. Another opera by this composer sees the title character singing the aria “Un bel dì” while waiting for Lieutenant Pinkerton to return. For 10 points, name this composer of Tosca and Madame Butterfly.

In his score to Shall We Dance, this man composed “Let’s Call the Whole Thing Off,” which Ella Fitzgerald covered in one of her three albums inspired by him. This composer used a A minor pentatonic scale in a blues-inspired aria about when “the livin’ is easy.'' Believing she “can teach [this composer] nothing,” Nadia Boulanger refused to (*) tutor this composer of an opera set in Catfish Row. In that opera by this composer, the aria “Summertime” is sung to Clara’s baby by Bess, whom Porgy aims to help. For 10 points, name this man, who also composed the jazz-influenced Rhapsody in Blue.

One prodigy of this instrument, Christian Li, made recordings of the fiendishly difficult La Ronde des Lutins. One piece for this instrument imitates flutes and french horns with ricochet and is nicknamed “The Hunt.” Giuseppe Tartini composed a sonata for this instrument titled (*) “Devil’s Trill.” 24 caprices for this instrument were written by Niccolo Paganini, who played one of these instruments made by the luthier Antonio Stradivari. The concertmaster of an orchestra plays this instrument, whose highest string is an E. For 10 points, name this highest-pitched string instrument.

This artist used copper paint to create a portrait of Jean-Michel Basquiat, which he then urinated on, in a work in his Oxidations series. Phtalo green was the only non-monochromatic color that this artist used in his Burning Cars series. This artist used mesh to transfer ink onto a canvas to create portraits of an (*) actress in his Marilyn Diptych, which was made using silk-screening. The Factory was the studio of this artist of thirty-two paintings, which only differ in the labels of varieties, like “split pea” and “tomato.” For 10 points, name this Pop artist, who painted Campbell’s Soup Cans.

A symphony by this composer was nicknamed after a chandelier fell at its premiere, but injured nobody. In the Andante second movement of a symphony by this composer, the violins softly play a theme beginning C-C-E-E-G-G-E before the theme ends with a loud G major chord. In an F# minor symphony by this composer, two violinists (*) stay on stage after performers blow out candles and leave. Anthony van Hoboken cataloged works by this man, whose twelve symphonies composed in London include the Surprise and Farewell Symphonies. For 10 points, name this German “father of the symphony.”

In a tondo painting by Sandro Boticelli, this figure writes the beginning of the Magnificat hymn. This figure sits on a throne on the front of Duccio’s Maesta. Due to the clothes draped around this figure, their body is unusually triangular in the only sculpture signed by Michelangelo. This figure holds the (*) infant John the Baptist in front of a mountainous landscape in a painting titled [this figure] of the Rocks. The angel Gabriel visits this figure in depictions of the Annunciation, while in the Pietà, this woman holds the body of her crucified son. For 10 points, name this mother of Jesus.

The central figure of a painting by this artist is thought to have been inspired by a Peruvian mummy. A red-haired woman kisses a man’s neck in a painting by this artist, inspiring its nickname, Vampire. Each person grieves alone in a painting inspired by the death of this artist’s sister (*) Sophie. That painting, Death in the Sickroom, is in this artist’s series The Frieze of Life. The eruption of Krakatoa may have inspired the red sky in a painting by this artist, in which a figure holds his face while doing the title action. For 10 points, name this Norwegian painter of The Scream.

One composer from this country used three metronomes at varying tempos to open his opera The Spanish Hour. Another composer from this country dedicated his Symphonie Espagnole to Pablo de Sarasate. A composer from this country was accused of plagiarizing his Rapsodie espagnole, which appears in his (*) Miroirs (‘Meer-awr”) suite. This country was home to the composer of a habanera, in which the title operatic character sings that “love is a rebellious bird” and is stabbed by Don Jose. For 10 points, name this country home to Maurice Ravel and the composer of Carmen, George Bizet.

The second movement of one symphony in A minor features a bouncy clarinet theme to represent a short-long rhythm, called this country’s “snap.” An overture that begins with a low 'stormy' cello theme was inspired by Fingal's Cave in this country. An instrument from this country called its “Great Highland” variety has (*) three drone pipes and is commonly paired with marching drums. Felix Mendelssohn’s trip to this country inspired his third symphony and the Hebrides Overture. Ireland and this country are the homes of bagpipes. For 10 points, the Glasgow Royal Concert Hall is in what country north of England?

One dance from this ballet features four young ballerinas holding hands before breaking apart and attempting to fly. One performer in this ballet stands en pointe while performing 32 fouettés in a pas de deux. It’s not by Mozart, but this ballet’s score was edited by Riccardo Drigo for its revival by (*) Lev Ivanov and Marius Petipa. Lead ballerinas playing the role of this ballet’s heroine often wear a black dress to also perform Odile, the daughter of the evil sorcerer von Rothbart. For 10 points, name this Tchaikovsky ballet, in which Odette is cursed to turn into the title bird.

These animals are sold on a road in front of the Salpêtriѐre asylum in a painting by Rosa Bonheur. In another painting, four of these animals are depicted with their legs stretched outward in a way that Eadward Muybridge’s photographs deemed anatomically impossible. In a different painting, the names (*) “Hannibal” and “Karolus Magnus” are carved into rocks below one of these animals. A white one of these animals appears in The Charging Chasseur by Théodore Géricault, who painted them racing in The Derby at Epsom. For 10 points, name this animal, which Napoleon rides in Napoleon Crossing the Alps.

One piece by this composer contains a series of rising arpeggios of the C minor chord progressions and is nicknamed “Ocean.” This composer’s piano sonata in B-flat minor contains an often excerpted “Funeral March,” and the poetry of Adam Mickiewicz (“MIN-kuh-vich”) inspired this man’s Four Ballades. One piece by this composer in (*) D-flat Major was supposedly inspired by the image of a dog chasing its tail. This man’s most famous etude was inspired by the November Uprising. For 10 points, name this Polish composer of the Minute Waltz and Revolutionary Etude.

Many paintings by a woman from this country were attributed to another artist from here, who depicted a laughing woman with an owl on her shoulder in Malle Babbe. Another artist from this country, who created the group portrait Syndics of the Drapers’ Guild, painted a man holding a blue and yellow (*) flag above a girl with a chicken hanging from her belt. A woman in a blue turban wears the title piece of jewelry in a painting by another artist from this country, which is Girl with a Pearl Earring. For 10 points, name this country, whose Golden Age painters include Rembrandt and Johannes Vermeer.

A variety of these artworks features royal coats of arms thought to be Polish, causing that variety to be named “Polonaise.” Two lamps appear to hang from a medallion in an artwork of this type named for the town of Ardabil. To depict the title figures’ status, a red one of these objects is placed on a table in (*) The Ambassadors, whose artist, Hans Holbein, often painted them. The asymmetrical Senneh knot was used in Persian examples of these artworks, which often feature flowers and Kufic Arabic calligraphy on them. Muslims pray on,  what textiles used to decorate floors?

A man appears as the base of a bunch of red roses in a work in this medium, which uses musical symbols to honor its dedicatee’s fondness for Beethoven. A kind of this material named for its similarity to milk, lattimo, was made by producers on the Venetian island of Murano. Instead of came bars, copper foil was used to join this material in making up the shade of (*) Tiffany lamps. Vitreous paint is used to color this material, which can be shaped by attaching it to the end of a hollow clay rod and blowing into the rod. For 10 points, name this material, which is “stained” in many church windows.

One section of this work begins with a melody of eighth notes E, G-sharp, G-sharp, G-sharp, then sixteenth notes F-sharp, E, to a high B. Jean-Jacques Rousseau arranged this work for solo flute, and its last movement utilizes pizzicato strings to depict rain. This work is performed alongside sonnet texts such as (*) “the drunkards have fallen asleep.” This work includes a viola playing “always forte” to depict a barking dog. This work was included in the composer’s Contest Between Invention and Harmony. For 10 points, name this set of four violin concertos, composed by Antonio Vivaldi.

Players of this instrument often learn from a set of 32 etudes by Cyrille Rose. This instrument’s predecessor, the chalumeau, names the first register of this instrument. Players of this instrument can “cross the break” to reach the second “clarion” register. One concerto for this instrument was originally written for a “basset” version of it. Anton (*) Stadler was the dedicatee of that A major concerto for this instrument by Mozart. Aaron Copland dedicated his concerto for this instrument to Benny Goodman. For 10 points, name this single-reeded woodwind instrument that is pitched in B-flat.

An artist who made many paintings of New York City in this style, Childe Hassam, was a prominent member of “The Ten.” In a painting blending this style with realism, two children play with paper lanterns among flowers; that painting, Carnation, Lily, Lily, Rose, was painted in Britain by (*) John Singer Sargent. Many portraits of mothers with children, such as The Child’s Bath, were painted in this style by Mary Cassatt. Louis Leroy coined this movement’s name while insulting a painting of a sunrise above a harbor. For 10 points, name this art movement characterized by light brushwork, which was practiced by Claude Monet.

It’s not Handel, but a truck stop on a highway inspired this composer’s Hallelujah Junction for two pianos. This composer described one of his works as a “memory space” and not a “requiem;” that work features a boy repeating the words “Missing.” One fanfare by this composer was commissioned for the Great Woods Festival and features a repeated woodblock ostinato. This composer of (*) Short Ride in a Fast Machine utilized a pre-recorded tape for a piece that lists the names of 9/11 victims. For 10 points, name this American minimalist composer of On the Transmigration of Souls and the opera Nixon in China.

Gensler designed the T5 addition to one of these places that made use of thin-shell construction for its roof. The design of one of these locations, named Taoyuan, was inspired by the catenary curved ceiling of another near Washington, DC. Renzo Piano won a Pritzker for designing one of these places on an artificial island, named (*) Kansai. The T·W·A Center designed by Eero Saarinen (“SAA-ri-nin”) is in one of these locations in New York, which is named after John F. Kennedy. For 10 points, name these locations, where planes take off from runways.

This work was moved from a German castle to the Altaussee (“all-tau-SAY”) salt mine during World War II. Grisaille (“gruh-SIGH”) depictions of St. John the Evangelist and St. John the Baptist appear in this work, which includes nude images of Adam and Eve on its sides. The most recent restoration of this work gave a more (*) humanoid face to the Lamb of God, whose blood is pouring into a chalice. The “Just Judges” panel appears in this work, whose central panel depicts the Adoration of the Mystic Lamb. For 10 points, name this polyptych altarpiece created by Hubert and Jan van Eyck.

One character played by this actor takes a job as a street sweeper and befriends a blind flower girl, played by Virginia Cherrill. In another film, this actor plays a character who dances with an inflatable globe and looks like an amnesiac barber. This director of City Lights played a character who attempts to eat his shoe; a (*) different one of his films depicts a factory worker who gets stuck inside a machine. This director of The Gold Rush and Modern Times parodied Hitler in another film. For 10 points, name this director of The Great Dictator, who often played as the “Little Tramp” with his iconic bowler hat and mustache.

This painting is analyzed in the preface to Michel Foucault’s The Order of Things. Nine paintings of doves appear in a series of 58 interpretations of this painting by Pablo Picasso. Juan del Mazo’s copies of two paintings by Peter Paul Rubens appears in the background of (*) this painting. The artist of this painting appears with a red cross on his chest while working at an easel. A dwarf and a dog are part of the entourage of the Infanta Margarita in this painting. For 10 points, name this painting of the “maids of honor” in a Spanish court, by Diego Velazquez.

The first two sections of this piece are played in reverse order in its final Lux Aeterna section. An Amen cadence is featured in a 12/8 Larghetto section of this work, which follows a Confutatis movement. A bass echoes a B-flat major melody played by the trombone in the “Tuba Mirum” section of this piece. Only eight bars of the (*) Lacrimosa section of this work was completed before its composer’s death. Count von Walsegg commissioned this work in D minor, which was completed by Franz Süssmayr after its composer’s 1791 death. For 10 points, name this mass for the dead by Mozart.
fine_arts.answer: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart’s Requiem Mass in D minor, K. 626

fine_arts.question: This man’s most famous work was originally published as the first tableaux for his Press Celebration Music suite. This composer’s final symphony in C major is only one movement. This composer utilized the english horn to depict the title bird of the underworld in another piece. This composer’s most famous piece was performed under titles like (*) Impromptu and ends with a namesake “Hymn.” This composer’s “The Swan of Tuonela” was included in his Lemminkäinen Suite, and he composed a nationalistic tone poem protesting Russian censorship. For 10 points, name this composer of Finlandia.

This artist was commissioned to create the Temple of Meditation by the Maharaja of Indore. Another work by this artist is a phallic depiction of Maria Bonaparte. This artist of Princess X designed a stack of 17 rhomboids as part of his World War I memorial at (*) Targu Jiu. This artist of Endless Column and Table of Silence created a series of works that was not considered art by customs officials. For 10 points, name this Romanian sculptor of Bird in Space.

This lower of the two featured instruments in Mozart's E-flat sinfonia concertante (sin-FOH-nee-ah kahn-sir-TAHN-tay) is labeled “da braccio” (dah BRAH-choh) in the sixth Brandenburg Concerto. This instrument is usually tuned “C G D A,” unlike a similar instrument called “da gamba.” Parts for this instrument are typical “inner voices” in Classical (*) quartets and are in the alto clef. This instrument is the second most numerous in most orchestras, after another instrument also played on the shoulder. For 10 points, name this bowed instrument pitched between the larger cello and smaller violin.

In an opera by this composer, a slave girl notes how the title character is “girdled with ice” in the aria (AH-ree-ah) “Tuche di gel sei cinta” (TOO kay dee jel say CHEEN-tah). The Jasmine Flower Song represents the title character of an opera by this composer, which was stopped by Arturo Toscanini (ar-ah-TOO-roh toh-skah-NEE-nee) in Act 3 where this man died writing. A (*) gong is struck three times in an opera by this composer, who wrote an aria sung by a man who answers three riddles and predicts a woman will not know his name, titled “Nessun Dorma” (nay-SOON DOR-mah). For 10 points, name this Italian composer of the China-set opera Turandot(too-RAN-dot).

A painting from this movement shows American flags hanging along Fifth Avenue in the rain. A painting by an artist from this movement depicts a woman in a striped dress cleaning a smaller person's feet in a water basin. After moving to Paris, an American artist who was part of this movement painted (*) The Child's Bath. Louis Leroy gave this movement its name after visiting an exhibition including a sketch-like painting of an orange sunrise. For 10 points, name this 19th-century art movement whose artists included Mary Cassatt and Claude Monet (MOH-nay).

A painting of one of these events in the Louvre includes depictions of Suleiman (SOO-lay-mon) the Magnificent and Charles V (the fifth). That ten-meter mannerist painting by Paolo Veronese (paa-OW-low ver-oh-NAY-zay) shows one of these events from John 2 (John chapter two). A convex (*) mirror surrounded with scenes from the Passion of Christ is in the back of a painting often titled for one of these events that shows a man in a fur-trimmed hat and a woman in a green dress. For 10 points, name this type of event for which Jan (yahn) van Eyck's Arnolfini (AR-nul-FEE-nee) Portrait was likely created, and which Veronese painted “at Cana.”

This composer called for a 5/8 (five eight)jarabe(hah-RAH-bay)-style trumpet solo before quoting “Goodbye, Old Paint” in a suite that uses clashing kettle drums and snare drum to depict a “Gun Battle.” This composer's Four Dance Episodes end with a movement that quotes old-time musician William Hamilton Stepp's version of “Bonaparte's Retreat.” In a (*) “doppio movimento” excerpt, this composer wrote five variations on Joseph Brackett's Shaker hymn “Simple Gifts.” For 10 points, name this American composer of the ballets Billy the Kid, Rodeo, and Appalachian Spring.

This object titles a Rodgers and Hart song cited as the earliest use of the '50s progression, whose lyrics state “You saw me standing alone / Without a dream in my heart.” The first number one hit for Mary Ford and Les Paul was titled “How High” this object is. This object now titles Bart Howard's (*) “In Other Words,” which declares “Fill my heart with song and let me sing forevermore.” For 10 points, a request to “see what spring is like on Jupiter and Mars” appears in a song whose title says to “Fly Me to” what heavenly body?

This was the primary instrument played by the lead artist on the album Moanin' who co-founded the Jazz Messengers. Art Blakey and Gene Krupa played this instrument, the latter collaborating with clarinetist Benny Goodman on “Sing, Sing, Sing.” Krupa also appeared on “Bernie's Tune,” which has a six-minute solo by another player of this instrument, (*) Buddy Rich. Performers of this instrument often choose between a traditional or a matched grip. For 10 points, name this jazz instrument which has bass and snare varieties.

A ballet based on writings by this author debuted in 1940, with Galina Ulanova (GAH-lee-nah oo-LAH-noh-vah) and Konstantin Sergeyev (kahn-stan-TEEN sair-GAYV) playing lead roles at the Kirov and a score incorporating a gavotte (gaa-VAWT) from the Classical symphony. For a 1962 ballet inspired by this author, George Balanchine (BAAL-an-sheen) adapted incidental music by Felix Mendelssohn, including the (*) “Wedding Dance.” The “Dance of the Knights” appears in a Sergei Prokofiev (SUR-gay pro-KAH-fee-ev) ballet named for a play by this author. For 10 points, name this author who inspired the piece “Montagues (MAHN-tug-yooz) and Capulets” (KAP-yoo-lets) in Prokofiev's Romeo and Juliet.

This artist painted six identically-dressed men in black and white in a painting that became an iconic symbol of a cigar brand. This artist's only seascape was stolen from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum. This artist of Syndics of the Drapers Guild and Storm on the Sea of Galilee, who used his wife (*) Saskia as a model, painted a gun blending into feathers on a hat and a girl in a white dress wearing a dead chicken on her waist. The militia of Frans Banning Cocq (“coke”) was painted by,  what Dutch artist of The Night Watch?

This city's Kimmel Center is home to a non-opera orchestra conducted by Montreal-born Yannick Nezet-Seguin (yah-NEEK NEZ-eh-say-gah). The Curtis Institute of Music is in this city. Eugene Ormandy (OR-man-dee) was the longtime conductor of a “Big Five” orchestra in this city that uses a “sound” pioneered by (*) Leopold Stokowski (staw-KAWV-skee) and plays the score in most of Fantasia. The theme to Monty Python's Flying Circus was a Sousa march named for an object in this city that legendarily rang on July 8, 1776. For 10 points, name this city whose Independence Hall is adjacent to the Liberty Bell.

An opera in this language that was the landmark season opener in 2021 at the Metropolitan Opera is called Fire Shut Up in My Bones. The conjurer Zodzetrick (zod-ZET-rik) appears in an opera in this language whose title character is saved from a wasp's nest by Remus. Jake sings “A Woman is a Sometime Thing” in an opera in this language in which (*) Crown kills Robbins and Clara sings the lullaby “Summertime.” Treemonisha(TREE-mun-EE-shuh) is a “ragtime opera” by Scott Joplin in,  what language of George Gershwin's Porgy and Bess?

Edward Burne-Jones helped lead a revival of this artform and used it to depict a woman named Cecilia playing a handheld organ. The United Nations headquarters commissioned a tribute to Dag Hammarskjöld (HAA-mark-HOLD) in this form. Another very blue artwork in this medium by Marc Chagall is named for America and is located in the (*) Art Institute of Chicago. Three pieces in this medium made to resemble a rose were saved from a 2019 fire. Louis Comfort Tiffany created many lampshades using,  what medium used to decorate Notre-Dame's (noh-truh DAHM's) windows?

A form of this artistic discipline that relies on “paraprosdokian” (pair-ah-pross-doak-ee-un) is the trademark style of Steven Wright and Mitch Hedberg. Highly regarded instances of this genre from the 21st century include Roy Wood's Imperfect Messenger and Tig (*) Notaro's use of this genre to discuss her cancer diagnosis. Hannah Gadsby both practices and critiques this performing art, particularly objecting to Dave Chappelle's routines in this discipline. For 10 points, name this performing art involving humorous stage monologues.

This architect's live-in partner Mamah Borthwick (MAH-muh BOR-thik) was murdered during a fire at his studio. In response to a challenge from Herbert Jacobs to design a good house for under $5000, this architect drew on his earlier Broadacre City project and a term coined by James Duff Law to create early (*) Usonian homes. This architect, who ran two studios called Taliesen (TAL-yay-sin), also designed a house for Edgar Kaufmann outside of Pittsburgh that was built over the Bear Run creek. For 10 points, name this American architect who designed the Fallingwater house.

Amy Beach stated that this piece inspired the Gaelic Symphony. A Largo theme in this symphony beginning with slurred notes “dotted eighth-sixteenth F, A-flat, long A-flat” evokes Harry Burleigh's singing. William Arms Fisher's (*) “Goin' Home” is based on an English horn solo from this symphony, whose first movement has a flute solo resembling “Swing Low, Sweet Chariot.” After finishing this symphony, its composer left Spillville to lead “Bohemian Days” at the World's Fair. For 10 points, a visit to the U.S. inspired what Antonín Dvořák (AAN-toh-neen div-or-JACK) symphony?

A painting in this format which illustrates a poem providing advice to women is titled Admonitions. Japanese examples of this format, called emakimono(aim-AH-kee-MOH-noh), include a 12th-century item with scenes from The Tale of Genji. The Rainbow Bridge is at the center of a painting in this format depicting Kaifeng (KAI-fung) in spring by Zhang Zeduan (jong zay-DWAN), titled (*)Along the River During the Qingming (ching-ming) Festival. Song Dynasty artists used silk or paper in this format, which was later replaced by codices (KAH-dis-eez). For 10 points, name this kind of painting that is unrolled for viewing.

This man poses against his horse Blueskin in a painting by John Trumbull. This man was depicted in a rotunda fresco painted by Constantino Brumidi (broo-MEE-dee) which shows his apotheosis (up-AH-thee-OH-sis). In a marble Jean-Antoine Houdon (ooh-don) sculpture located in Virginia's (*) State Capitol, this man leans against a cane. Three old women stand in front of a painting of this man in Grant Wood's Daughters of Revolution. Emmanuel Leutze (loyt-zuh) depicted this man standing in a boat fording an icy river. For 10 points, name this man depicted Crossing the Delaware and on the one-dollar bill.

The second section of this piece repeats a triplet motif which the composer whistled at home to his wife Caroline Alice. An amateur pianist warms up in the second section of this piece, whose sections are often titled for initials such as “C.A.E.” This composition, dedicated to Dorabella and other (*) “friends pictured within,” depicts Augustus Jaeger (YAY-gur) in the section “Nimrod.” Sections of this piece are based on a mysterious theme that may be “Rule, Britannia.” For 10 points, name this composition by Edward Elgar.

The Uzura-gakure(oo-zoo-rah-gah-koo-ray) is one of these people's “earth techniques” that requires curling into a ball. The Bansenshūkai(ban-shen-soo-kai) details how these people were trained in the Iga and Koga regions. Objects used by these people include the air-filled mizugumo (mee-zoo-goh-moh), which supposedly let them (*) walk on water, and kunai, which were used to stab holes into walls. These people's practice of tanuki-gakure(tah-noo-kee-gah-koo-ray) involved climbing trees to hide, possibly during assassination missions. For 10 points, name these covert agents in feudal Japan who are often portrayed as clad in black.

Musicians from this cultural region include Dock Boggs and Bascom Lamar Lunsford. A style of music developed in a smaller part of this region was promoted by Bill Monroe and Earl Scruggs. The Carter Family and a genre called “old time fiddle” originated in this region, whose dulcimer and (*) banjo music inspired Dolly Parton and bluegrass musicians. Songs like “Solidarity Forever” were used for coal mining strikes in this region. The folk song “Cumberland Gap” was written in,  what mountainous region of the Eastern United States?

Marc Breaux (BRO) and Dee Dee Wood collaborated on the choreography for this musical's song “Step in Time.” In this musical, two children clean their room during a song that describes “an element of fun” in “every job that must be done.” Before (*) Jane and Michael visit their father in this musical, a character sings “Feed the Birds.” Bert the chimney-sweep sings “Chim Chim Cher-ee” in this musical, whose title character sings “A Spoonful of Sugar” while looking after the Banks children. For 10 points, name this musical about a magical nanny.

28 copies of a sculpture of this character are depicted in Salvador Dalí's painting The Hallucinogenic Toreador(TOR-ee-uh-dor). A mammoth ivory figurine sometimes known by this proper name was unearthed in Hohle Fels (HOH-leh FELSS); another figurine known by this name is from Willendorf (VEEL-en-DORF). A sculpture of this character, attributed to Alexandros of Antioch (ANT-ee-ock), is missing (*) both arms. A 1486 painting shows this nude deity standing on a seashell. For 10 points, name this Roman goddess depicted in a sculpture rediscovered on Milos (MEE-lowsh), whose “Birth” was painted by Sandro Botticelli (BOH-tee-CHEL-ay).

A shamisen (SHAH-mee-sen) accompanies traditional performances involving these objects in a practice known as “joruri” (JOR-oo-ree). Three people called the “omozukai” (oh-moh-zoo-kai), “hidarizukai” (hee-dah-ree-zoo-kai), and “ashizukai” (ah-see-zoo-kai) collaborate to hold these objects during performances. “Kuroko” (koo-ROH-koh) are people who wear (*) black robes and use these objects to perform. These objects are central to a genre of theater that inspired the later kabuki (kuh-BOO-kee). Japanese bunraku (BOON-rah-koo) uses,  what painted objects that are manipulated by human operators to perform plays?

This song is interpolated into John Corigliano’s (kuh-RIL-ee-AH-noh’s) piece The Mannheim Rocket. Six variations on this song open the first book of violin instruction by Shinichi (she-NEE-chee) Suzuki. A 19th-century poem by Jane Taylor provides the most common set of lyrics to this song, which was the subject of twelve variations by (*) Mozart. The French melody 'Ah! vous dirai-je, maman' (AH VOO deer-ai juh MAH-mahn) became this song in English. The alphabet song shares a tune with,  what song about an object “like a diamond in the sky?”

A painting of one of these events is believed to depict Victorine Meurent (myoo-rawn) along with two of the artist's brothers and was inspired by Titian's (TEE-shun's)Pastoral Concert. Two people in straw hats lean against a diagonal railing in a painting of one of these events. A pink-striped awning frames a painting of one of these events held for a (*) boating party, by Pierre-Auguste Renoir (ren-wawr). Two clothed men and a naked woman lounge by a river in an Edouard Manet (man-AY) painting titled after,  what event “on the Grass”?

history.question: This man’s Secretary of State supported Yahya Khan's military regime during the Bangladesh genocide. He lost what would become the closest Presidential Election in the 20th century, but later went on to be elected as President 8 years later. This man was staunchly anti-communist, which gave him cover during his visit to the People’s Republic of (*) China, coining the historical phrase 'Only *this man* could go to China'. He terminated the US Dollar's ties to the gold standard, effectively ending the Bretton Woods System, and he also created the Environmental Protection Agency. FTP, name this man, who was the 37th President of the United States and resigned after the Watergate Scandal.

The legalisation of the CNT-FAI and the handing over of the CEDA campaign chest were events that immediately preceded this war. The Army of Africa participated in this war and was led by a man who would later become dictator of his country. When that man in this war entered his nation's capital, he proclaimed “We have passed”. The bombing of (*) Guernica by the German condor legion took place during this war, inspiring a Picasso painting named for the destroyed town. George Orwell wrote Homage to Catalonia, a personal account of his experiences during this war. FTP, name this civil war, won by Francisco Franco and his nationalist faction.

This ruler waged the 24 year-long Livonian War against his neighbours until he brokered a truce at Yam-Zapolsky with Stephen Báthory. A famous painting depicting this ruler holding his dead son was painted by Ilya Repin. This ruler created a secret service known as the Oprichniki, and an infantry unit (*) known as the Streltsy. After he murdered his heir-apparent, Ivan Ivanovich, the mentally disabled Feodor I was forced to take the throne when this ruler died, starting the ‘Time of Troubles’. FTP, name this first Tsar of Russia, who had a very terrifying epithet.

A governor of this Empire defected and converted to Christianity, who then went on to form the League of Lezhë (“le-sher”). A ruler of this emperor with the epithet ‘the Grim’ captured the last Abbasid Caliph, who had been a guest of the Mamluk Sultanate. An elite infantry unit was formed through the capturing and conversion of Christian (*) children, which known as the Janissaries. Mehmed II of this empire conquered and established his capital at Constantinople, the so-called 'City of the World's Desire', giving him the epithet 'the Conqueror'. FTP, name this Empire that was dissolved after the creation of the Republic of Turkey and was once ruled by Suleiman the Magnificent.

This man’s ‘Three-anti’ and ‘Five-anti’ campaigns were designed to tackle corruption and dissidence within his government. His designated successor removed the 'Gang of Four' from political power, one of the members of the gang being this man's wife. The Xi’an incident led to the kidnapping of this man’s rival and the eventual creation (*) of the Second United Front.The 100 Flowers Campaign and the Cultural Revolution all took place during this man’s time in power. After winning the Chinese Civil War, he declared the People’s Republic of China in 1949. FTP, name this communist chairman who wrote the Little Red Book and launched the devastating Great Leap Forward.

Chess Grandmaster Mikhail Tal was born in this country. Augusts Vilhelms Ulmanis turned this country into an authoritarian regime as its fourth President. The Duchy of Courland was a vassal of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, its territory now residing within this modern day country. This country was occupied by Germany during World War II, its capital becoming the new capital of the Reichskommisariat Ostland (*) . The capital of this country also was the centre of a Baltic German monastic order founded in the 13th century known as the Livonian Knights. FTP, name this country which declared independence from the USSR in 1991 and whose capital is Riga.

A ruler of this family was captured by the Ottoman Empire and as punishment was forced to listen to lute music. Karim Khakimov was a Soviet diplomat who was the first to establish ties between the USSR and this family. A backstab by the British allowed this family to conquer the Kingdom of Hejaz, which at the time was ruled by Hussein bin Ali. The number of members of this family is (*) approximately 15,000. Primary opponents of this family included the Rasheed dynasty and the Hashemite dynasty. Faisal was the first of his family to declare himself as the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques. The kingdom created by this family was the last country in the world to allow women to drive. FTP, name this family, the rulers of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.

This man supported the Simba rebellion along with around a hundred volunteers. This man wrote in his memoirs about the crippling poverty he had witnessed in Peru. Alberto Korda took a photograph of this man, which the Maryland Institute College of Art has called “the most famous photograph (*) in the world”. This man supported President Jacobo Árbenz’s reforms in Guatemala, and when he was overthrown it convinced this man that‘revolutionary struggle’ was the only answer. With help from the CIA, this man was captured in Bolivia and executed. FTP, name this communist revolutionary who helped overthrow Fulgencio Batista in the Cuban revolution and who famously wore a beret.

One of this Empire’s coats of arms was known as the Quaternion Eagle. During the ‘Salian Period’ this Empire experienced internal strife. This empire came to blows with the Swiss Confederacy, which seeked independence from its rule. A ruler of this empire attempted to wage war against the Lombard (*) League, which was supported by the Papacy. Another ruler officially dissolved this empire in 1806, when it became clear that Napoleon may have been attempting to declare himself as the emperor of this empire. The Peace of Westphalia brought an end to the 30 years war, a conflict which primarily took place within the borders of this empire. FTP, name this German-based empire that is often referred to as the ‘First Reich’ and was ruled by the Von Habsburgs for over 3 centuries.

It’s not the hundred years war, but this war's name misrepresents how long the war actually lasted. A smaller conflict within this war was known as the Fantastic War, in which Portugal defeated Spain. On the brink of military victory, Tsar Peter III upon ascending to the throne immediately withdrew from this war. The battle of Plassey took place during this war, resulting in the annexation of Bengal by the British East India Company. In this war, Austrian attempts to regain the province (*) of Silesia were thwarted by the King of Prussia, Frederick the Great. The American front to this war was called the French and Indian War, and saw the 22 year old lieutenant colonel George Washington fight on the British side. FTP, name this 18th century war that was fought on every continent between Great Britain and France.

Under the dictatorship of Higinio Morínigo, this country seeked better relations with the Axis powers. Rafael Franco was a communist President of this country who fled after he was overthrown in a right-wing military coup. A majority of this country’s population identify as Mestizo and its national currency is the Guaraní. Under one president, this country lost (*) possibly up to 70% of its population in a war against the Triple Alliance; that president was Francisco Solano López. This country fought the Chaco War against its neighbour Bolivia, which this country won. FTP, name this country, which borders Brazil and Argentina and whose capital is Asunción.

According to the New York Times, this leader once compared democracy to prostitution. Department 900 was the name of a special intelligence unit created by this ruler to combat Saddam Hussein. That unit is now called the Quds Force. A common theory was that this ruler was in fact the 12th (*) Imam, who had mysteriously disappeared a thousand years earlier. He deposed Mohammad Reza Pahlavi and replaced his country’s monarchy with an Islamic Theocracy. FTP, name this first Ayatollah of the Islamic Republic of Iran, who overthrew the Shah in the 1979 Iranian Revolution.

This man called Hitler “the greatest living German” and during World War II the Germans preferred this man over Oswald Mosely to lead a possible future British puppet state. This man refused to join Winston Churchill’s wartime cabinet despite being asked to. As prime minister, this man was the leader of his party during the ‘Coupon election’which saw his party (*) split into two factions temporarily. As Chancellor, this man introduced the People’s Budget, oversaw the Shell Crisis, and was embroiled in the Marconi Scandal. This man was the only British Prime Minister who did not speak English as a first language, as he was a native Welsh speaker. FTP, name this man, the last Liberal prime minister of the United Kingdom.

This location was subject to a conquest by the Emir of Ifriqiya (“ifri-key-a”) in the 9th century. It’s not Britain, but In the 11th century, this island was partially invaded by the Normans and later ruled by Robert the Fox. The Roman boat king Sextus Pompeius used this location as a headquarters to blockade Italy during a war named after this location (*) . After a successful operation involving the allied invasion of this island, Hitler was forced to abandon the Kursk Offensive. That operation was codenamed ‘Husky’. Administrative divisions of this island include Palermo and Messina. FTP, name this island, the largest in the mediterranean sea and nicknamed the ‘boot’ of Italy.

This man was the only survivor of the Chichijima incident, with the other eight men being cannibalised. As ambassador to the UN, this man presided over the defeat of the ‘China Question’ where Taiwan was replaced by China as a permanent member of the Security Council. This man appeared as a character on the Simpsons (*) as a next door neighbour to the Simpsons themselves. This man ran for the Republican nomination in the 1980 Presidential Election, but lost to Ronald Reagan. After later being elected as President he would preside over the Gulf War and the signing of NAFTA. His broken promise to not raise taxes was a key reason for his failure to win reelection in 1992. FTP, name this President, the father of Jeb and George W. Bush.

This man restored Tigranes V to the Armenian throne and defeated enemy tribes in the Illyicum Campaign. One Roman consul made fun of this man for marrying his wife whilst she was pregnant with another man's child. This man was awarded multiple triumphs alongside his lifelong friend Marcus (*) Agrippa. Due to a devastating loss at the Battle of Teutoburg Forest, this man would give up his ambitions of conquering Germania. After winning a war against his long time rival Mark Antony, he would hold sole political power over all of Rome. FTP, name this first Roman Emperor, who gives his name to a month of the year.

Sir Patrick Allen has been the governor of this country since the late 2000s. Tacky's War was a large-scale slave rebellion that took place within this country. This country is split up into 14 parishes and 3 counties. This country’s two-party system is dominated by the Labour Party and the People's National Party. Under the ambitious‘Western Design’, this country was turned into an English colony, seizing it from their previous (*) owners, the Spanish. This country was the largest economy in the British West Indies. Alexander Bustamante was the first Prime Minister of this country after it gained its independence in 1962. FTP, name this Caribbean island nation whose flag has the colours Green, Black, and Yellow.

A propaganda campaign encouraging immigration to this region referred to it as the ‘Great Northern Wilderness’. The Treaty of Nerchinsk used the Amur River as the new northern boundary between the Russian Empire and this region. The queue hairstyle was used to identify and harass people from this region in Australia and San Francisco. The Mukden (*) incident was a false flag attack which prompted the Empire of Japan to invade this region and create a puppet state under Emperor Puyi. Over the centuries Han Chinese culture slowly overtook the native culture of this region under the Qing dynasty. FTP, name this region of China that is bordered by Russia to its north and Korea to its south.

Baron Roman von Ungern-Sternberg attempted to subjugate this ethnic group during the chaos of the Russian Civil War. The Four Oirat was a confederation of tribes that primarily comprised this ethnic group. A kurultai was (*) a military, political, and religious council used by this ethnic group to select their new rulers. After gaining independence from the Qing (ch-ing) in the Xinhai (Shin-High) Revolution, this ethnic group was ruled by the Bogd Khan. FTP, name this ethnic group which gives their name to the largest contiguous empire in world history, which was ruled by Genghis Khan.

Under one Prime Minister of this country, a dominant party democracy was established, known as the ‘1955 System’. That prime minister had a grandson who also became prime minister of this country. A period of economic stagnation starting in the 1990s was known as this country’s ‘Lost Decade’. Of the 31 Prime Ministers that have served this country since World War II, 24 of them have been members of (*) the Liberal Democratic Party. Article 9 of this country’s constitution forbids them from using any threat of force or declaring any offensive wars. This country experienced the ‘post-war economic miracle’after its reconstruction period. FTP, name this country, which was led by Shinzo Abe and is sometimes known as the Land of the Rising Sun.

During the reign of the Isaurian dynasty, this Empire fought for its survival against multiple encroaching empires. This empire briefly took land from the Visigothic kingdom under the pretence of helping to crush a rebellion in the region. During the 11th Century, a woman came to dominate the politics of this empire, holding sway over many of its rulers. That woman was called Zoe. During the fourth (*) crusade, catholics destroyed this empire and replaced it with the Latin Empire, despite the fact that this empire was Christian. One general of this empire conquered and subjugated the Vandal Kingdom and also regained Italy for this empire, that general was Belisaurius. FTP, name this empire, once led by Justinian the Great and whose capital was Constantinople.

This event began in Blue Island and orders during the response to this event were given by Attorney General, Richard Olney. Participants in this event set World’s Fair buildings in Jackson Park on fire. Governor John Atgeld was opposed to the federal response to this event, which occurred after the disruption of the (*) mail service. The leader of this event would later run in five elections as the Socialist Party’s nominee for president. For 10 points, name this 1894 event in which workers led by Eugene Debs refused to transport trains with cars from a certain company.

During this event, a telegram beginning “Your Action Desperate” was sent by Bertrand Russell. This event began after one side initiated Operation Anadyr, and one of the casualties in this event was Rudolf Anderson. In this event, an Illinois politician told Valerian (*) Zorin to “just answer yes or no”, and that same politician said“I am prepared to wait for my answer until Hell freezes over.” Vasily Arkhipov successfully prevented the launch of a nuclear torpedo in,  what 1962 crisis caused when the USSR placed nuclear weapons in a namesake Caribbean country?

This man’s agricultural advisor did not believe in Mendelian genetics and claimed that offspring could inherit vernalization. This leader targeted Jews in the Doctor’s Plot towards the end of his reign. This man ended the New Economic Policy of his predecessor and instituted a (*) command economy in its place. This man relied on Konstantin Rokossovsky and Georgy Zhukov to defend his nation from a German invasion in World War II. For 10 points, name this leader who succeeded Vladimir Lenin as the leader of the Soviet Union.

This president had his political career launched by Tom Penderagast’s political machine, which this man referred to as a “democratic organization.” An assassination attempt on this president was conducted by Griselio Torresola and Oscar Callazo, the former of whom was killed by (*) Leslie Coffelt. This man, who won re-election while criticizing the Do-Nothing Congress, vetoed the Taft-Hartley Act. This man was president when the atomic bombs were dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. For 10 points, name this 33rd President of the US, the successor of FDR.

This man refused to engage his countrymen at the Battle of Aspromonte, and his wife fought at the Battles of Imbituba and Laguna. This man gave a one word telegram “Obbedisco” during the Battle of Bezzecca while leading the Hunters of the Alps. This man fought against the Blancos in the (*) Uruguayan Civil War, and after the Treaty of Villafranca, he became an enemy of Camillo di Cavour. This man led the Expedition of the Thousand in his conquest of Sicily. For 10 points, name this leader of the Red Shirts who worked for Italian Unification.

This leader, who issued the Organic Decree, was tutored early in his life by Simon Rodriguez. This man wrote the Cartagena Manifesto before his Admirable Campaign, and also issued the Decree of War to the Death. This man wrote a letter expressing his republican virtues while in exile in (*) Jamaica. This man fought alongside Antonio de Sucre, and he met Jose de San Martin at the Guayaquil Conference. This man created Gran Colombia, which later split into three different countries. For 10 points, name this “liberator” of many South American countries.

This ruler built a statue of Jupiter and himself on the Temple Mount. This ruler had Lucius Quietus executed for his connections to Trajan. This man created the Panhellion confederation of Greek states. This man’s young lover, Antonius, led a cult around this ruler following his death. This man saw the completion of the (*) Pantheon and put down the Bar Kokhba Revolt in Judea. For 10 points, name this successor of Trajan who built a namesake wall between Scotland and England.

This man faced a rebellion caused in part by the passage of the House Tax Law, in which around 100 people rode to Quakerstown and captured federal tax assessors. This man then pardoned the rebellion’s leader, John Fries [“freeze”]. This man said “facts are stubborn things” during his defense of John Preston for his role in the Boston Massacre. This president’s (*) midnight appointments led to the court case Marbury v. Madison, and he and his successor both died on July 4th, 1826. For 10 points, name this man who lost re-election in the election of 1800, the second President of the United States.

During this dynasty’s rule, Dong Quan was laid siege to by Vietnamese rebels led by Le Loi. During this dynasty, the Chongzhen emperor hanged himself. Immediately before this dynasty, Li Zicheng led a rebellion that declared itself the Shun Dynasty. The voyages of (*) Zheng He began in this dynasty, during which the Yongle emperor constructed the Forbidden City. This dynasty was established after the Hongwu emperor took control of Beijing in 1368. For 10 points, name this penultimate Chinese dynasty, which succeeded the Yuan and preceded the Qing.

This nation temporarily had a female dictator, Ana Pauker, who led its Communist Party after World War II. One of this nation’s kings had a mistress named Magda Lupescu; that king, Carol II, had his prime minister resign in protest when he returned to this country in 1930. This nation’s final dictator relied on his secret police, the (*) Securitate, to maintain order and repress his enemies. That man and his wife, Elena, were captured and executed by firing squad in this country’s 1989 Revolution. For 10 points, name this nation once ruled by Nicolae Ceausescu [“Chow-SHESH-Koo”] from its capital, Bucharest.

During one of these conflicts, the USS San Jacinto violated a neutrality agreement in order to aid one side in bombarding the Taku Forts. A viceroy from the losing side in one of these conflicts wrote an open letter to the monarch of the winning side, asking “Where is your conscience?” That leader, Lin Zexu, (*) confiscated over 2 million pounds of a certain good and had it burned in Humen to begin the first one of these conflicts. Hong Kong and the Kowloon Peninsula were ceded by the Qing Dynasty to Britain during these conflicts. For 10 points, name these wars between China and various Western powers over the legalization of a certain narcotic.

This man conquered Strasbourg during the War of the Reunions, an act that was legitimized in the Truce of Ratisbon. This ruler instituted the policy of dragonnades in order to force Protestants in his kingdom to convert. This ruler, who was revolted against in the Fronde, revoked the (*) Edict of Nantes. This ruler’s attempt to put his grandson Philip of Anjou on the Spanish throne resulted in the War of the Spanish Succession. For 10 points, name this Bourbon monarch and so-called “Sun King” who ruled France from 1643 to 1715.

The last emperor of this empire, Brihadratha, was overthrown and executed by Pushyamitra Shunga. This empire was visited by the Seleucid diplomat Megasthenes, who wrote about this empire in his book Indica. This empire’s first emperor’s advisor, Chanakya, wrote the (*) Arthashatra, a treatise on political science. A famous ruler of this empire constructed a pillar with four lions at Sarnath. That leader converted to Buddhism after seeing the bloodshed of the Kalinga war. For 10 points, name this empire that was ruled by Chandragupta and Ashoka.

At Valcour Island, this man’s actions delayed the invasion of New York by Guy Carleton. After recapturing Philadelphia, this man married Peggy Shippen. One of his campaigns saw the death of Richard Montgomery in a failed invasion of Canada. This man captured Fort Ticonderoga with the help of the (*) Green Mountain Boys. This man, who was exposed when John André revealed this man’s plan to surrender West Point, clashed with Horatio Gates before leading the colonists to victory in the Battle of Saratoga. For 10 points, name this colonial general who defected to the British in the American Revolution.

The so-called “Napoleon” of this movement was Neal Dow, who later fought in the Civil War, but was wounded at the siege of Port Hudson. Izzy Einstein disguised himself as a gravedigger to enforce the goal of this movement, and shut down many (*) speakeasies. George Remus and Bugs Moran, the latter of whom’s men were killed in the St. Valentine's Day Massacre, acted as bootleggers during this movement. The goal of this movement was enacted nationwide by the Volstead Act, which enforced the 18th Amendment. Wayne Wheeler was an advocate of,  what movement that suggested banning alcohol?

This ruler formed the League of Armed Neutrality to oppose Britain during the American Revolutionary War. The Confederation of the Bar opposed this ruler after she put Stanislaw Poniatowski on the throne of Poland. Under this ruler, Jews were confined to the Pale of Settlement. One lover of this ruler, Grigory (*) Potemkin, built fake villages to impress her during a national tour. During her reign, this ruler faced a revolt from Ukrainian Cossacks led by Yemelyan Pugachev. For 10 points, name this last empress regnant of Russia who ruled from 1762 to 1796.

This empire successfully aided the Count of Enghien in capturing Nice from the Duke of Savoy. This empire fought against Louis II at the Battle of Mohacs. One ruler of this empire had Ibrahim Pasha killed on his orders, and lost to Prince Eugene of Savoy at the siege of (*) Vienna. This empire was the westernmost of the so-called “Gunpowder Empires”, and this empire was referred to as the “Sick Man of Europe” before World War I. This empire reached its peak under Suleiman the Magnificent. For 10 points, name this empire that, under Mehmed II, sacked Constantinople in 1453.

While instigating this case, the Comité de Citoyens [koh-mee-tay day see-to-yen] stated “In defending the cause of liberty, we met with defeat but not with ignominy”. One lawyer in this case, Albion Tourgee, wrote the newspaper column “A Bystander’s Notes”. The law in question in this case was called “a badge of servitude” by the lone dissenter. This case started when a man who was (*) one-eighth black refused to sit in a segregated train car in Louisiana in 1890. John Marshall Harlan was the lone dissenter in,  what 1896 Supreme Court case that established the idea of “separate but equal?”

This leader discovered several species of hydrozoa while studying marine biology. Shortly before this leader’s death, The Sun ran a headline stating “Let the Bastard Rot in Hell.” This leader’s Prime Minister was killed by the League of Blood in the May 15th Incident. This man renounced his (*) divinity and gave a namesake radio broadcast marking his country’s surrender after the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. For 10 points, name this father of Akihito who served as Emperor of Japan during World War II.

This dynasty came to power after its founder defeated Xiang Yu at Gaixia. This dynasty faced the revolt of the Trung sisters in Vietnam, and its emperor Wudi defeated the Xiongnu Confederation. This dynasty was briefly interrupted by the Xin Dynasty of Wang Mang, separating it into its (*) Eastern and Western periods. This dynasty faced the Yellow Turban Rebellion, and its collapse precipitated the Three Kingdoms period. For 10 points, name this dynasty that shares its name with China’s majority ethnic group.

Prior to this event, Count Emicho and his followers massacred thousands of Jews in the Rhineland massacres. During this event, forces led by Robert of Flanders, Bohemond of Otranto, Raymond of Toulouse, and Godfrey of Bouillon won the battle of Ascalon after meeting with Byzantine emperor (*) Alexios Komnenos. This event was called for with cries of “Deus Vult!” [pronounced day-uss vult] at the Council of Clermont. For 10 points, name this first successful attempt to recapture the Holy Land by Christian forces, which was called for by Pope Urban II.

This man’s armies won the Battle of Kalka River against the Kievan Rus, and he won the Battle of Badger Mouth after an ambassador sent by this man was executed. This man killed his half-brother Bekhter over a hunting dispute, and later in his life he developed the (*) Yassa law code. His wife Borte was kidnapped by the Merkits, and he defeated them with the help of his half-brother, Jamukha, who this man later killed. This man was succeeded by his son Ogedei, and his grandson was the founder of the Yuan Dynasty. For 10 points, name this grandfather of Kublai Khan, the first Mongol ruler.

Information about this man’s motivations come from journals kept by his attorney, T.R. Gray. Born just before the death of Gabriel Prosser, this man reported visions such as drops of blood on corn, hieroglyphic writings on leaves, and a spectral man in the sky. This man acted on those visions by attempting to capture the (*) Jerusalem armory after killing Joseph Travis’s family. This man was captured and put to death in Southampton County after killing sixty white residents. For 10 points, name this man who gave his “Confessions”after leading the largest slave revolt in Virginia history in 1831.

This man’s wife, Katharina von Bora, was a nun who called this man “Sir Doctor” throughout her life. This man called the members of an uprising he inspired “filthy swine”; that uprising was the Peasants’ War. This man attended the Marburg Colloquy along with Ulrich (*) Zwingli. This man said “Here I stand; I can do no other” when he was called to recant his beliefs at the Diet of Worms. This man, who was excommunicated by Pope Leo X, criticized Johann Tetzel for the sale of indulgences. For 10 points, name this German monk who sparked the Protestant Reformation by writing the 95 Theses.

After a battle against this nation, a rival queen stated, “My men have become women, and my women have become men.” One king of this nation sent his general Harpagus to finish a conquest. In order to establish religious freedom in this empire, that ruler declared the (*) Edict of Restoration. This nation, which faced the Ionian Revolt, was ruled by satraps. This empire decisively lost the Battle of Salamis to an alliance of Greek city-states despite vastly outnumbering them. For 10 points, name this empire ruled by kings such as Xerxes I and Cyrus the Great.

This man started a business with his neighbor Maurice Clark, who this man would later buy out. An Indiana subsidiary of this man’s business was fined $22 million for violating federal railroad tariff laws. This man closed a facility in Pittsburgh in a feud with Tom Scott before the death of this man’s ally, Cornelius (*) Vanderbilt. This man, whose grandson served as Gerald Ford’s Vice President, had his business practices exposed by Ida Tarbell. This competitor of Andrew Carnegie saw his business broken up in 1911. For 10 points, name this founder of the Standard Oil company, the richest person in American history.

This country’s king was killed in 1934 by Vlado Chernozemski, who was aided by the Ustaše. That king, Alexander I, abolished this country’s constitution and instituted the January 6th Dictatorship. During World War II, this country’s royalist government-in-exile signed the Treaty of Vis in a truce with the communist-leaning (*) partisans. This country’s longtime dictator helped found the Non-Aligned Movement and was the first communist leader in Europe to break his alignment with the Soviet Union. For 10 points, name this former nation led by Josip Broz Tito that split into nations such as Serbia and Croatia in the late 1990s.

Description acceptable: Despite supporting this event, the National Front was banned and suppressed two years after it occurred. This event was triggered by the burning of the Cinema Rex in Abadan, which was blamed on the SAVAK secret police by one side. The leader of this event had earlier been exiled over his opposition to the (*) White Revolution. Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi fled into exile during this event, leaving his opponent Shapour Bhaktiar in power, who was later denounced as a traitor and overthrown by this event’s leader. For 10 points, name this event in which a Middle Eastern country’s monarchy was overthrown and replaced with an Islamic Republic under Ayatollah Khomeini.

An expedition by Alfred Gaselee helped end this conflict, during which one side crossed the Amur River. A woman’s brigade known as the Red Lanterns formed during this conflict, which included a seige at Legation Quarter. Clemens von Ketteler was murdered during this conflict, and a Muslim force known as the Kansu Braves allied with (*) Dowager Empress Cixi during this conflict. The Open Door Policy was created in response to this event, which was ended by the Eight-Nation Alliance. For 10 points, name this anti-foreigner Chinese rebellion led by the “Righteous and Harmonious Fists.”

This empire reconquered much of its lost territory during the reign of Basil II. This empire’s ban on idolatry was overturned in 787 by a council convened by Empress Irene. This empire was defeated at the 1071 battle of (*) Manzikert, allowing for the Sultanate of Rum to be created by the Seljuk Turks. In 1453, this empire was finally destroyed when its capital fell to the Ottoman Empire. For 10 points, name this eastern continuation of the Roman Empire, with the capital of Constantinople.

During this battle, civilians constructed a system of dugouts known as “Prairie Dogs Village”. The losing side in this battle had to endure bombardments commanded by David Porter. The winning side in this battle took Port Gibson and Grand Gulf before blocking the forces of Joseph Johnston. John (*) Pemberton’s forces retreated from Black River to the site of this battle, which resulted in the Confederates’ territory being divided. For 10 points, name this Battle in which Ulysses S. Grant captured one of the last Confederate strongholds on the Mississippi River, a victory for the Union a day after Gettysburg.

This man successfully defended Aaron Burr from treason charges following Burr’s duel with Alexander Hamilton, and this man later participated in a duel with John Randolph in which both parties survived. This man’s plan included federal infrastructure projects like the National Road and the Maysville Road. This man was part of the Great (*) Triumvirate alongside Daniel Webster and John Calhoun. This man was offered the post of Secretary of State as part of the “Corrupt Bargain” in the Election of 1824. For 10 points, name the Whig senator from Kentucky who proposed the American System and was known as the Great Compromiser.

A predecessor to this organization was proposed and led by Richard von Coudenhove-Kalergi. Politicians who supported the creation of this organization include Italian Prime Minister Alcide de Gasperi and French Christian Democrat Robert Schuman. Predecessors to this organization include an (*) Economic Community founded by the 1957 Treaty of Rome, and a coal and steel trading organization during the Cold War. This organization was created by the 1992 Treaty of Maastricht. For 10 points, name this organization of nations from a certain continent, including countries like Germany, France, and Italy.

This man prosecuted Cimon for accepting bribes from Alexander I of Macedon. This man’s mistress, Aspasia, attracted many intellectual thinkers to her house, including Socrtes. This man’s father, Xanthippus, commanded a navy at the Battle of Mycale. This man issued sanctions on the state of (*) Megara through the Megarian Decree. This man consolidated the Delian League under his city-state and gave a funeral oration during a war. For 10 points, name this Athenian leader who fought the Peloponnesian War and built the Parthenon.

One side’s attacks during this battle were successful in forcing the other side out of Telnitz, but the arrival of Davout III Corps repulsed those attacks. Troops led by Marshal Soult captured Pratzen Heights in this battle, forcing Mikhail Kutuzov to retreat.
